instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message: replaced <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips because of cycling issue, the cycling has stopped and i have solid 5v with 0.40 amps, but no power, ppbus is stabile at 12.30v and device is not in dfu mode, curious what to check next, seem to be missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
Did you follow all the steps to enter DFU ,ode?
Check SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages; on the small coils around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_D3H</SIGNAL> 12.30v 
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3v 
P1V1SLPS2R_SW1 1.1v
P1V8SLPS2R_SW0 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2v

just noticed that top right port <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is cycling every 12 sec or so 
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> have been replaced

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message: what steps are you referring to, for entering dfu mode, keyboard combo isn't working, , how to i force enter dfu

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message: Use SWK003 pads; see last page schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message:
was not able to force dfu,
still have 5v .30amp all ports, ppbus still only 12.30,
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is 3.3v, all ports still 5v .30 amp, i have 3 units all with same issue, 
thermal cam shows T2 getting warm, not hot temp about 90 degrees

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0.40amp no power
threads.message:
How did you try DFU with SWK003?
Must solder a tiny wire and connect charger.
When machine appears in AC2, cut off the wire.
